title: 1.2: Basic Properties
summary: Learn to update particle color and size with simple constant values
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to use UpdateColorBlock and UpdateSizeBlock to change particle properties. We'll start with simple constant values - no time-based calculations yet. You'll create a complete particle system from scratch with color and size updates.
steps: Create a SystemBlock - this is the root of your particle system
Create a CreateParticleBlock to emit particles
Set an initial color using ParticleInputBlock (e.g., orange: Color4(1, 0.5, 0, 1))
Set an initial size using ParticleInputBlock (e.g., 0.3)
Connect the color and size to CreateParticleBlock
Add a PointShapeBlock to emit particles from a single point
Add an UpdatePositionBlock to handle particle movement
Get Position and ScaledDirection using ParticleInputBlock
Add Position and ScaledDirection using ParticleMathBlock (Add operation)
Connect the result to UpdatePositionBlock's position input
Connect the InitialColor contextual value to UpdateColorBlock's color input
Connect a constant size value to UpdateSizeBlock's size input
Chain the blocks: CreateParticle → PointShape → UpdatePosition → UpdateColor → UpdateSize → SystemBlock
Add a ParticleTextureSourceBlock to provide a texture for the particles
Observe how particles now have consistent color and size throughout their lifetime

blocks.name: UpdateColorBlock
blocks.description: Updates the color of particles each frame. In this lesson, we use it with a constant color value. In later lessons, we'll learn to change color over time.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

properties.name: color
properties.description: The color to apply to the particle. Can be a constant Color4 value or a contextual value like InitialColor.

blocks.name: UpdateSizeBlock
blocks.description: Updates the size of particles each frame. In this lesson, we use it with a constant size value. In later lessons, we'll learn to change size over time.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

properties.name: size
properties.description: The size value to apply. Can be a constant value or calculated using math operations.

blocks.name: ParticleInputBlock (InitialColor)
blocks.description: Retrieves the initial color of a particle when it was created. This is a contextual value that remembers the color from CreateParticleBlock.

properties.name: contextualValue
properties.description: The type of contextual data - InitialColor in this case

blocks.name: PointShapeBlock
blocks.description: Emits particles from a single point. Used in this lesson to create particles that move in a straight line.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter

codeCopy: This lesson introduces UpdateColorBlock and UpdateSizeBlock. These blocks allow us to modify particle properties each frame. In this lesson, we use constant values - the color and size don't change over time. This is the foundation for more complex effects we'll learn in later lessons. The key concept is chaining update blocks: each block receives the particle from the previous block, modifies it, and passes it to the next block.
objectives: Learn to use UpdateColorBlock and UpdateSizeBlock
Understand how to chain multiple update blocks together
Use InitialColor contextual value to maintain particle color
Apply constant values to particle properties
Understand the update block chain: UpdatePosition → UpdateColor → UpdateSize

commonMistakes.mistake: Chaining update blocks in wrong order
commonMistakes.explanation: Update blocks must be chained in a specific order. UpdatePosition should come first, then UpdateColor, then UpdateSize.
commonMistakes.solution: Chain blocks in order: UpdatePosition → UpdateColor → UpdateSize → SystemBlock. Each block receives the particle from the previous block.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using wrong contextual value for color
commonMistakes.explanation: InitialColor retrieves the color set when the particle was created. Using Position or Direction will cause errors.
commonMistakes.solution: Use NodeParticleContextualSources.InitialColor for UpdateColorBlock when you want to maintain the original particle color.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not connecting update blocks to SystemBlock
commonMistakes.explanation: Update blocks must be added to SystemBlock's updateBlocks array, otherwise they won't be executed.
commonMistakes.solution: Add all update blocks to SystemBlock: systemBlock.updateBlocks.push(updatePositionBlock, updateColorBlock, updateSizeBlock).

homework: Try different color values (red, blue, green, etc.)
Experiment with different size values (0.1, 0.5, 1.0, etc.)
Try using different emitter shapes (BoxShapeBlock, ConeShapeBlock)
Combine different colors and sizes to see how they affect the visual appearance
